Award.AwardTitle: Building Bridges to the Balkans-Mathematical Biology in Sofia 2014, June 22-27, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2014 International Conference on Mathematical Methods and Models in Biosciences and Young Scientists School (BIOMATH 2014) will be hosted by the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences during June 22-27, 2014 in Sofia, Bulgaria. The BIOMATH 2014 conference focuses on the interplay between modeling, mathematical analysis, and numerical simulation in epidemiology and cancer modeling, among other mathematical biology fields. Mentoring and training of junior faculty and advanced graduate students is a central part of the BIOMATH 2014 conference. This award supports participation by US-based advanced graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and junior faculty without access to other grant support. Priority will be given to the support of students and new doctorates from groups underrepresented in the mathematical sciences.

There are many U.S. graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and beginning faculty working at the interface of mathematics and biology. The award will enable such US-based researchers to attend the BIOMATH 2014 conference. The BIOMATH 2014 conference will provide a unique opportunity for their participation, an excellent educational experience, and mentoring and interaction with some of the most active and leading researchers in mathematical biology. The meeting will serve as a vehicle for enhancing and supporting their career developments. It is expected that the conference will catalyze many successful interdisciplinary collaborations between the BIOMATH participants from the United States and Eastern Europe.

More information about the BIOMATH 2014 conference is available at http://www.biomath.bg/2014/index.php.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the travel of seven U.S. participants, particularly advanced graduate students and researchers in the early stages of their careers, to attend the 2014 International Conference on Mathematical Methods and Models in Biosciences and Young Scientists School (BIOMATH 2014).

The BIOMATH 2014 conference took place from 22 June to 27 June 2014 at the campus of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences in Sofia, Bulgaria (http://www.biomath.bg/2014/).  The conference series BIOMATH is devoted to recent research in biosciences based on applications of mathematics in the biological sciences as well as mathematics applied to or motivated by biological applications. It is a multidisciplinary meeting forum for researchers who develop and apply mathematical and computational tools to the study of phenomena in the broad fields of biology, ecology, medicine, biotechnology, bioengineering, and environmental science, among others. Over 90 participants from 22 countries from all over the world attended the BIOMATH 2014 meeting. More than 30 of them were junior scholars who gave oral presentations: 15 from Bulgaria, 7 from USA, and 6 from South Africa, among others; as part of the School for Young Scientists (SYS). Out of the 7 junior US participants, there were two M.Sc. students, three PhD. students, and two Postdoctoral research fellows (2 female, 2 Hispanic, 1 African American). 

The BIOMATH 2014 conference provided an excellent educational experience for the US-based graduate students and junior faculty participants. The conference environment enabled fruitful discussions among all participants.  In particular all junior researchers were mentored by the invited keynote speakers and other senior faculty participants. Many opportunities were provided to plan new research directions in mathematical biology. Current research results will be published in the journals “Mathematics and Computation with Simulations" and “BIOMATH”. The presentations by the BIOMATH 2014 graduate students and junior faculty participants were assessed both by their peers and a jury, constructive feedback was provided, and presentation prizes were awarded accordingly. In addition, several of the established scholars were asked to present “hot topics & open problems in biomathematics" and to act as moderators during two SYS discussion sessions. Besides the scientific program, the BIOMATH 2014 social program included a get-together party for the young scientists, a welcome party with a poster session, an official conference dinner, and a one-day-excursion.
